text: Family Member 1: And she does yoga. Doctor: I’m very relaxed in here. Oh my gosh. (laughing) Family Member 1: She teaches yoga too Doctor. Doctor: Are you okay? Patient: Yeah, I'm fine. I’m just concerned about that PSA going up. Doctor: Yeah so we gotta start. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So again, we kind of ran through the gamut, you know, you need some sort of chemo. So, you know, we talked last time the chemo was just ready to go, just chemo chemo. Then we have the chemo that's a trial with regular chemo versus a pill version. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Now, that's not the first time we've done a pill version. It's the first time we've done it for this chemo. But like, there's an all time chemotherapy called FIVFU, that they made a pill version of that called Xeloda. So that's an active practice if you have like colon cancer, it's just not something we routinely use for prostate, but the idea has been around so it's not super novel, but we've never done it for this type of chemotherapy. So if it works, it's Patient: So is this what you want to put me on? Doctor: Yes, because the other one and just for timing wise, the other one is also fine with chemo, but the vitamin C, that's high dose. So again, natural but still high doses requires IV. You're here twice a week, every week sort of indefinitely. So it's a big time sink. So I kind of wanted to at least offer you the less intensive one, but also So I think very effective. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: That’s a different study. Doctor: Because that only works against the bone. Patient: Oh. The only new findings are really this one on your bone scan – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: and that we are very well aware about that we know. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So those were there even before you started the Xofigo. Patient: Right. Doctor: The radiation. Patient: Right. Doctor: So right now I think we will be in just watch and wait mode because I see no recompelling reason to put you on a new treatment.

text: Family Member: Right, but I’m just… Doctor: Yeah, the standard… Family Member: Are there different types of… Doctor: Yes, there are different… Family Member: Okay. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Typically, we don’t use that medicine unless it drops. Huh, over the long haul, you might get, huh, injury to the longest nerves in your body. Those are your fingertips and to your toes. Huh, you get numbness. Huh, so we try to go out as many as ten cycles. Most people notice it by the sixth or seventh. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But I’m going to ask you every time can you zip up your thing? Can you button your pants? Can you button your shirt? If you tell me I can’t, I’m going to stop. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: But if your shirt’s coming in and it’s unbuttoned, even though you tell me you did, I’m not going to believe you. Okay? I have ways to check. Patient: Right. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay? Because I don’t want to go too far with the numbness, huh, if that’s a possibility. Patient: Okay. Doctor: One of the things about the positive thing about the vitamin C is there is some bit of the people get less numbness. Huh, normally after three or four doses of the chemotherapy, huh, we have a sense of whether it’s helping. Your PSA may be lower. Your pain may be better. Huh, huh, those are sort of some of the clues. Okay? Huh, if we feel like it’s, you are getting better, we’re going to keep going as far as ten treatments. Huh, if after three or four doses, your pain’s worse, your PSA is higher, huh, I might even get scans after the fourth cycle to follow your lymph nodes. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Huh, because if your PSA is going up, and your lymph nodes are getting bigger, we’re not going to keep giving you the chemotherapy if it’s causing all those side effects. Patient: Right.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
